info.game_comments: (Leonard Maltin: Hi, I'm Leonard Maltin, and I give this next show four stars.)

(1, 1).clue: 6'4" but going on 7 feet with hat; a Whig earlier in life; a fan of the theater, unfortunately

(2, 1).clue: Though this circus entrepreneur's name is on the Nabisco box, he was never cut in on the profits

(4, 1).clue: As this, Abbie Rabine would become Miss America 2002 if Katie Harman throws in the sash

(5, 1).clue: (Leonard Maltin starts things off.) I once wrote that only a real-life Grumpy could fail to love this 1937 animated feature
(5, 1).correct response: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs

(6, 1).clue: If you were born between June 21 & July 22, this is your Zodiac sign

(1, 2).clue: Had a hiss-y fit & a "checker-ed" past; was eventually resigned to his fate

(2, 2).clue: In 2002 Nabisco's Animal Crackers celebrated this anniversary in the U.S.

(3, 2).clue: Like a delinquent dad, "D is for..."

(4, 2).clue: The Los Angeles Unified School District has a pool of about 6,500 of these

(5, 2).clue: Steve Martin's first starring feature, Maltin describes it as "The misadventures of a terminally stupid man"

(6, 2).clue: A linstock was the long stick once used to hold the match when firing this weapon

(1, 3).clue: Doubt you'll see him in a "middle name's the same" category; played by Gary Sinese; gave 'em hell

(2, 3).clue: Nabisco added the string to the box to allow it to be used as one of these holiday items

(4, 3).clue: For the Glen Campbell 45-rpm version of "Wichita Lineman", it was "True Grit"

(5, 3).clue: (Leonard Maltin continues.) I've called this 1941 classic "A stunning film in every way" & Orson Welles was only 25 years old when he made it!

(1, 4).clue: Born in Iowa; helped feed the unfortunate; sucked up 444 electoral votes in 1928

(2, 4).clue: The current menagerie in the Nabisco box has 2 of these (perhaps ursa major & ursa minor)

(4, 4).clue: It's the position of the horse that comes in second

(5, 4).clue: Maltin tells us this 1951 classic was "gorgeously filmed on location in the Belgian Congo"

(1, 5).clue: First thought on his sudden presidency--"I thought I could swing it"; to him, silence was golden

(2, 5).clue: In a song sung by a curly-topped kid, this line precedes "Monkees and rabbits loop the loop"

(3, 5).clue: Some sit in it, "J is for..."

(4, 5).clue: For Flirt & Reenie in a 1951 Broadway production of "The Dark at the Top of the Stairs", it was Tuesday Weld

(5, 5).clue: (Leonard Maltin wraps up the category for us.) What Hitchcock did with this 1960 film was brilliant.  Imagine, killing off your major star in the first portion of the film

(6, 5).clue: It's the duck seen here looking pretty as a picture

(1, 1).clue: For a great view of Mars, astronomy.com suggests using a Wratten no. 25 filter in this appropriate color

(2, 1).clue: The Motion Picture Association of America gave "Pokemon 3: The Movie" this rating

(3, 1).clue: This state claims the Mark Twain Expressway, part of I-70, as the first project of the Interstate Highway System

(4, 1).clue: In golf, number of holes played in the Masters Tournament, without a playoff

(5, 1).clue: This poet who helped the Greeks fight the Turks was the 6th baron in his family line

(6, 1).clue: A magician's word to ensure a trick's success

(1, 2).clue: The late comet discoverer Gene Shoemaker had his ashes shot to this heavenly body he'd always wanted to visit

(2, 2).clue: This letter followed "John" in the title of a 2002 Denzel Washington film

(3, 2).clue: Indianapolis' I-465 has that number because it's an urban beltway connecting with this 2-digit interstate

(4, 2).clue: In Major League Baseball, the minimum number of pitches to reach a "full count"

(5, 2).clue: The 1st Baron Verulam, some believe he wrote Shakespeare's plays--but others say that's hogwash

(1, 3).clue: (Hi, my name's Charlie Hobaugh and I'm on the Space Shuttle Atlantis.) This instant orange-flavored drink was popular with kids in the '60s because astronauts used to drink it

(2, 3).clue: In "Who's Who" entries, name & occupation are usually followed by this single-letter abbreviation

(3, 3).clue: It's the state with the most interstate mileage, including Interstates 10, 20 & 45

(4, 3).clue: Michael Johnson won Olympic Gold in 2000 by covering this many meters in 43.84 seconds

(5, 3).clue: John Maynard, 1st Baron Keynes of Tilton, made his biggest mark in this field

(6, 3).clue: An original inhabitant from earliest times

(1, 4).clue: Not to be confused with KFC, the KSC is this space-y place

(2, 4).clue: A "tacky" sailing expression says, the shortest distance between 2 points is this letter

(3, 4).clue: The only 3000-mile insterstate is I-90, which stats in Boston & ends in this west coast metropolis

(4, 4).clue: The NBA gives an annual award to this "Man" who comes off the bench

(5, 4).clue: Baron Clive of Plassey began his career as a clerk in this company in Madras

(6, 4).clue: Capital of the United Arab Emirates

(1, 5).clue: Stargazers know that the planetarium in Copenhagen is named for this Danish astronomer

(2, 5).clue: Copyright on writings is indicated by a C in a circle; on sound recordings, by this letter in a circle

(3, 5).clue: It runs 1,900 miles from Miami to Houlton, Maine

(4, 5).clue: (Here's Sarah.) As Ty Murray could tell you, a professional bullrider must remain on the animal for this many seconds.  Yee haw!

(5, 5).clue: The German baron born Israel Beer Josaphat founded this news agency in Paris in 1851

(6, 5).clue: (Here's Cheryl.) It's the ritual act I'm performing

(0, 0).clue: Besides English & Spanish, 2 of the 4 other languages in which the U.S. census 2000 questionnaires were printed
